CPU FDE: Definition
The cycle by which the CPU fetches an instruction from memory, decodes it, then executes it, repeating continuously
The stage in the FDE cycle in which the CPU retrieves the next instruction from main memory
The stage in the FDE cycle in which the CPU interprets the fetched instruction and determines required actions
The stage in the FDE cycle in which the CPU carries out the instruction (e.g. perform arithmetic, read/write memory)
The hardware component that executes instructions and processes data
The part of the CPU that performs arithmetic and logical operations
The part of the CPU that directs and controls the operations of the CPU, including decoding instructions and orchestrating data movement
Small, very fast storage locations within the CPU used to hold data and instructions during execution
A register that holds the address of the next instruction to be fetched
A register that stores the address in memory to which the CPU wants to read or write
A register that holds the data value read from or to be written into memory
A register that holds the instruction currently being decoded/executed
An electronic component that produces a regular signal (pulse) to synchronise operations inside the CPU
The frequency at which the CPU clock ticks (often measured in hertz), determining how many FDE cycles per second
Electrical pathways that transfer data, addresses or control signals between CPU, memory and peripherals
The bus that carries memory addresses from the CPU to memory
The bus that carries actual data between CPU, memory and peripherals
The bus that carries control signals (for example read/write, interrupt) between CPU and other components
An architecture in which program instructions and data share the same memory and paths (buses)
Very fast temporary memory located close to the CPU used to reduce time to access frequently used data
A signal to the CPU indicating that an external event needs immediate attention, pausing the normal FDE cycle
A computer system built into a larger device to control its operations
Non‑volatile storage (e.g. hard disk, SSD) used to store data and programs when power is off
